The content on the DVD is data that can be copied an infinite number of times. By the rules of supply and demand, that data's potential supply is higher than the demand, hence that the actual value can be reduced to zero. So no, the only way you can argue that the DVD has value one must pay a real monetary price for is if you acknowledge that you are paying for the entire physical product. At that point it's still fair to have people copy it free knowing they don't have an authentic copy of the DVD. It's up to the consumer if they think it is worth that value to pay.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Piracy has shown that sectors of the economy that center around the creative arts have fundamental issues with how they can exist within a capitalist framework. As technology progresses, the market adapts. But with the creative arts we see the ability to monetize the works in the same sort of model as other product centered economies as an challenge and one that the arts are losing in. AI art is already becoming an existential threat to visual artists with people calling it stealing. Soon AI will be able to replicate more complicated mediums like music and films.

The arts need to recognize the limits of their medium in making them money (at least in the industrial way that has been tried for the last 100 years), and either try traditional models like patronage and small scale artisan approaches, or think of something radically new. Crying about pirates is the defeated cry of a failing industry.

How’s this as the story of a fifth Indiana Jones film instead of “Dial Of Destiny”; this’ll be inspired by this fan poster and based off its title, “The Secret Of Life”:


“Indiana Jones And The Secret Of Life”:

Harrison Ford is back as Indy in the late 1960s. He’s hung up the whip after settling down with Marian, however, Indy’s son Mutt Williams, who is now an adventurer of his own, asks his father to help him investigate a strange occurrence in the North Pole. Indy is initially reluctant but agrees and goes with his son (this could maybe be made better but anyways somehow Indy needs to go along or get there.)
After taking a plane, landing, and going into a cave there they are taken by a couple of radiant beings through some tunnels to a vast underground city, with numerous crystalline structures and floating vehicles of some kind. Indy can remark that maybe Admiral Byrd’s accounts weren’t so fanciful after all. They are taken to the ruler of the cities. After some conversations, Indy asks who these people are and where they have been, having been around for thousands upon thousands of years. The ruler tells Indy that they are a spiritually advanced race that created humanity and that the reason for their absence from humanity and their lack of willingness to help is because they have become depressed with what humanity has done and believe they are incapable of being saved.

1/2

Isn't the message of Avatar spoiled by the sheer contrivance that is the Na'vi? Its preaches primitive environmentalism, but humans aren't long lived giants, who are connected to a world conciousness, which grants them control of massive predator animals.

Humanity evolved under the tyranny of nature. Hunter Gatherers lived brutish lives, where the cycles of nature could suddenly ruin a community. They didn't have a mother earth to coddle them.
